turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll argument now Number 99-1994, Nevada v. Floyd Hicks.
Mr. Howle.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I would like to make three principal points this morning.
The first is that state officials should not be sued in tribal courts.
Tribal jurisdiction over state officials would be inconsistent with their status.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You mean, ever, for anything, no matter what?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, as long as they were acting in a representative capacity for the state.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: This comes to us in the context of a state official who went to the tribal court to get authority to carry out a search warrant, and was given a warrant with certain terms and conditions to go on the reservation and carry it out.
And if the allegation is that the officer did not follow the limitations in the authorized warrant, you think the tribal court can never have jurisdiction over those actions of the officer?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Your Honor, I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's your position?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, that is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Suppose he just goes and buys some gasoline and doesn't pay for it.
Say he drives up to the tribal gas station, buys some gasoline, drives off, doesn't pay for it.
I mean, can they sue him for the money in the tribal court?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --The answer is no, Your Honor, not in tribal court, but in state or federal court, and there is a remedy there.
We're not here to suggest that there's no remedy--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Okay, what is your authority for this broad initial proposition you're making?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --The authority is--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What case?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Oliphant, which describes a divestiture of tribal jurisdiction which is inconsistent with the tribe's status.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that's criminal jurisdiction, is it not?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it was.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about civil jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: In the case of civil jurisdiction, the case of National Farmers Union also requires an examination of the tribe's sovereignty, and to the extent it's been divested.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I read another brief... a 1934 opinion of the Solicitor General who said that the tribes under Acts passed by Congress had the basic sovereignty that they had for generations, unless it was taken away.
And I guess for generations they could have sued people who went and bought gasoline without paying for it.
I don't know if it always would have been gasoline, but I assume a basic contract action would be within their grant, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, first of all I'm not prepared to concede that much regarding even a nonmember in a private capacity, but with regard to state officials, there are special considerations.
The state officials are protected, we know, with a certain immunity which has constitutional dimensions.

And our position is that that in conjunction with the Court's instruction to examine the extent to which tribes have been divested implicitly because of their statuses as tribes results in the rule that jurisdiction over state officials has been divested.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Howle, I could understand a position that says when a state official is acting pursuant to state authority... there's a warrant, a state warrant... that that person can't be questioned in tribal court.
But suppose this officer, instead of going in with a warrant, just went in, rammed down the door, beat up the plaintiff.
He's still wearing his state uniform, and he's still looking for evidence of whatever animal that was... would you say that even in such a case there would be no tribal court jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: We would, Your Honor.
No tribal court jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You're not even making a distinction that's often made in these public employment cases between acting within the scope of one's authority and going so far beyond the pale of anything that would fit within that authority as to be on a frolic of one's own.
You wouldn't--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: We're suggesting a higher standard, and that being acting in a representative capacity, and that's a standard that we see employed, albeit in an ambiguous fashion--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --What does that mean?
He at least has to believe that he's pursuing the state's business?
Suppose he's wearing his uniform and he just goes on the reservation to beat up one of the members of the tribe that he doesn't like, but he's in uniform and he's on duty.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --That's a difficult case, Your Honor.
I'll concede, but this is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Gee, I don't think it's difficult at all.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --That isn't this case, though.
There's no allegation that our officials acted outside of any state authority.
The only allegation regarding scope of authority is the constitutional violation alleged, and otherwise the complaint alleges that they were acting as game wardens.
They do what game wardens do, and they get warrants and search for evidence of crime that was committed off the reservation by a reservation member.
And this is a core state function.
It's a peace officer function.
Nevada has to be able to enforce its criminal laws within its own borders.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I be sure I understand your position... are you saying that your immunity rule would only apply when the state official is acting within the scope of his authority?
Is that what your position is?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I phrase it differently, Your Honor.
I suggest a representative capacity being the standard.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, supposing he goes beyond his representative capacity and does what Justice Scalia describes.
Would he be immune or not?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Well, I think that... I think in that case the analysis then falls back to a different test, and that being the ordinary test for a private citizen.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But that isn't this frolic of his own or something like that?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Surely he'd be treated differently if he were an officer, but unrelated to any of the state business.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But why don't you go the whole hog and say that it's your position that it ought to be a question for the state court and not for the tribal court whether, in fact, he was just going in to beat up a tribal member he didn't like, or he was going on state business.
That's doubtless going to be one of the issues in the case, and that whole case should belong in state court rather than tribal court?
That's not an irrational position.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: No, it isn't, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that the position you're taking?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I'll take that position, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why not take it?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if you take that position, what about the case in which the officer acknowledges that he's not on state business?
How about that officer?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: That officer would then have to be tested under the appropriate standard for a private citizen, and tribal jurisdiction over private citizens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So then your view is that the immunity attaches if the officer acknowledges that he was not within his state authority.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I'm sorry?
The immunity would not attach--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's backwards, yes, you're right.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Does your argument depend on the fact simply that there is uncertainty under the jurisdictional standard as to how far the tribal court's jurisdiction goes, or would your argument be the same if the statute were clear beyond a peradventure of a doubt that someone who was acting in what you describe as official capacity but is being sued in his individual capacity would nonetheless be subject to jurisdiction?

In other words, are you making this argument in order to construe a vague jurisdictional grant, or are you making this argument into something that would be entitled to prevail no matter how clear the statutory grant was?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: First of all, Your Honor, there is... I'm sorry, I may have misapprehended.
There isn't a statutory grant here, save for the civil rights law of the federal government.
But our first position is that there is a categorical rule that state officials doing state business should not be subject to the tribal court's jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If I agree with you on that as to state officers enforcing the state's criminal laws, which is what was at issue here, do I have to agree with you with regard to all other state officers?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Not that... yes, Your Honor, I think so.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Professors at state universities?
Anybody else?

I mean, there's a distinctive aspect of the enforcement of the criminal law, and that is that the tribe has no authority to stop the state from enforcing its criminal laws on the reservation, and one can very plausibly argue that along with that goes no authority to determine whether persons acting in that criminal law enforcement capacity have gone beyond the scope of their authority.
That's very rational.
But I wouldn't have to extend that to other state officers, would I?
Because in the civil field the state can't just walk in and take over the enforcement of civil laws on the reservation.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Your Honor, you're correct.
The state can't take over a reservation, but the state carries on a multitude of functions on reservations outside of those--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, do you take the position that the state has authority to send its criminal law enforcement officials onto a tribal reservation to carry out state criminal law functions?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I do take that position, but I acknowledge that it's tentatively based--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There's some question about that, isn't there?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --There is indeed--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Like the right to exclude on the part of the tribal authorities?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: From the reservation?
There is no... what would you point to for the extraordinary notion that the state criminal law enforcement officers have total freedom to go on a reservation to carry out criminal law functions?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I point to the fact that state--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is there some law or some case that you can point to for that?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Yes, the case of Ex rel re v. Martin, and I believe McBrattney described the existence of state criminal jurisdiction on reservations.
It's not an exclusive jurisdiction that the tribes--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: For crimes committed off... I perhaps put my hypothetical a little too broadly, but in fact the tribal courts do not have jurisdiction to try for crimes committed off reservation, do they?
If a crime is committed off reservation, it's not within the jurisdiction of the tribal court, is it?
Even if it's a crime committed by a tribal member, or a tribe--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I think that's correct, Your Honor.
I'd say it with some uncertainty--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well, I think it's pretty crucial to your case, and I assume that to be the case.

I assume that to be the law... that the state has the authority to enforce its state criminal laws with regard to offenses committed off the reservation even when that requires the state to go on the reservation to get the culprit.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Yes.
That all is correct with my understanding, too.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not up to the tribe to enforce that law.
It must be up to the state to enforce it.
Since only the state can enforce it, I assume the state can go on the reservation.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: The state also has criminal jurisdiction on reservations over a nonmember crime.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: If that much is right, then getting the back-up of the tribal court's approval for the warrant was just a polite gesture, meaning a form that was not necessary legally.
In other words, here we do have an investigation of something that occurred off the reservation.
The warrant is to go on the reservation to investigate, but the crime itself was off reservation.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And I think Justice Scalia asked you, would the tribal court have authority to prosecute a case that occurred off the reservation.
I think you said the answer was no.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I think that's correct.
I am tentative on that answer--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you're not certain about it.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I know in this case that the tribe would not prosecute that crime.
I do know that for a certainty.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But then the next thing is that the crime occurs off the reservation.
The warrant is to go on the reservation and conduct a search there.

As you understand it, it is not necessary to get any permission of any kind from the tribe, because what the state official is enforcing is an investigation for a crime that occurred off the reservation.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe that the state's physical jurisdictions follows its legal jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So you think it was not necessary to get the tribal court's permission to carry out a search warrant on a house belonging to a tribal member on the reservation?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor, although I admit I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I think that's an unusual proposition.
Do you cite anything in your brief for that proposition?
I thought we took it as a given that the tribal court had to authorize the search.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --In my reply brief on page eighteen, I've referenced some authorities that are indirectly related that establish a criminal jurisdiction for the states on reservations.
It's only by reasoning and inference that I get to the conclusion that we have this authority, and if we had not sought the tribal judge's approval, perhaps we'd be here on that issue as well.
I confess there's... it's a great area of uncertainty, but it is a concurrent jurisdiction that the state and the tribe have on reservations.
Reservations are still part of the state, and so the state has to be able to perform these functions in order to do its job properly with law enforcement.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I certainly wouldn't think that the state's ability to enforce criminal laws off the reservation is going to be dependent upon whether a tribal court will deign to issue a search warrant or not.
I mean, that would be a tremendous incursion upon the state's sovereignty that it can't enforce its criminal laws unless it gets a tribal court to let it go on and search for the offense.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Exactly.
And that's the position we have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I assume that to be pretty clear law.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Yes.
Another point we've made is the way that this--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Where did you take that position, because I didn't see the--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
It's on page eighteen of my reply brief, in the second paragraph.
The argument also incorrectly assumes state officials are powerless to pursue state law enforcement objectives on a reservation, except with the tribe's consent.
And here I've identified the fact that states do have authority over off-reservation crimes committed by tribal members, and that reservations are part of the state within which they occur.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --So now you are confirming that it was a matter of a test to ask the tribe, but it was not necessary.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, although we did ask the tribal judge on both occasions out of deference to the tribe.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And he granted permission, did he not?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What statutes are there concerning state criminal law jurisdiction with respect to either on-reservation or off-reservation crimes?
Are there some federal statutes that speak to that issue?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: There is federal statute on the matter.
It eludes me at the moment.
Certainly Public Law 280 was a grant to certain states of jurisdiction on reservations.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Was that, in effect, pure in Nevada?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: It was in the past, but it isn't now.
All that jurisdiction has been--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Then you're not relying on Public Law 280?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --No, we're not.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: While we're on the subject of federal statutes, one thing you said surprised me, and I just want to make sure I understand it.
Is it your position... do you understand that there is no federal statutory recognition for tribal jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Not in this case, not with this tribe.
There--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, what about other cases?
I mean--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Treaties and statutes unique to different tribes, there's a whole--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --But there are all specific to the tribe or to the jurisdiction?
There is no general statutory recognition?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --As far as I know, Your Honor, that's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why, just out of curiosity... not quite just out of curiosity, but why didn't the defendant instead of sort of engaging in all of these proceedings for ten years... why didn't he simply remove the case to federal court?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I'm sorry?
The defendant--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why didn't the defendant in this case simply remove it to the federal court?
There is no--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --Your Honor, that goes to the question brought up in U.S. brief... I don't see removal authority.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Well, it says... you'd have to read the word state to mean state or a tribe.
But one... maybe you can't, maybe you can't.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't that hard?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You say that as though it's the simplest thing in the world.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I thought for you it might be.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, that is an issue.
But if that's possible, then doesn't that offer a perfect solution?
There's no problem.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: There's no perfect, exact solution.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Any state official's not bothered, all he has to do is remove, and then that would be the end of any potential conflict.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: That would be a--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Howle, if that had been the case, then this Court would not have had to go through the motions it went through in those two cases that says you have to exhaust the tribe, and then you can go into the district court at the end of the line.
It's only because you couldn't get out... there was... I am unaware of any authority that says you can remove from the tribal court to any other court.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I'm not aware of any either, Your Honor.
We spent three years in tribal court arguing our immunity questions.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Did you try to remove it?

Maybe it's just obviously impossible to do, and if it is impossible to do, then the conflict of interest that you're talking about exists, but that's why I wondered... I see a lot of cases where apparently it starts off in the tribal court, and then they're over in the federal court, and there are injunctions being issued back and forth.
What's the basis?
Is there some... I'm trying to see if this conflict of interest is necessarily there.
The basis is you can't remove.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: We considered removal but didn't see that it was specifically provided for in the statutes.
We also were aware of the exhaustion requirements, and we attempted to exhaust.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And, of course, removal would not be an option... removal to a federal court would not be an option.

The whole matter would have to be left in tribal court, even though there was an enforcement action with respect to state criminal law, if a 1983 action hadn't been part of the claim, if it had just been the tribal claim under tribal law.
Then you would have been stuck.
Even on the fanciful reading of Section 1441, you couldn't get it into federal court.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: My question is best reserved for the Solicitor General.
I mean, you're not aware it?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Maybe he can explain... or she, I'm sorry.
On the question of immunity, we did spend three years trying to exhaust this issue in tribal court, and only then went to the federal court with an independent action.
And our position on the immunity issue is that immunity is a bar to suit, and it should be decided when it's raised.
And therefore, if the tribal court won't acknowledge the immunity--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is the source of immunity law here?
I mean, I take it your position is it can't just be finally determined by the tribe but should finally be determined by the law of Nevada?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --It depends on the claim, Your Honor, on a 1983 claim, assuming that there's one available in tribal court.
I guess that would be a question of federal law.
The other ones would be answered in reference to the state law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If it's a 1983 action, then immunity is determined under qualified immunity doctrines laid down under 1983?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Possibly so, Your Honor, although that is a question as well.
The whole question of whether 1983 is available in tribal court, I think, is cast in doubt.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What was the basis of the action in the district court?
It was 1983, was it not?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: In the tribal court, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No, this case comes to us from the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And so there obviously must have been some action brought in the district court.
The District Court of Nevada.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Nevada brought the action.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Nevada brought the action.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: It was an independent action to enjoin the tribal court after three years there.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Those two cases that we had, that said that's what you do.
You go to the district court.
And I think in those cases they said the reason why you have to do that is that there is no removal.
That was the whole point of Nevada coming into the district court.
If you could have removed to get there, you wouldn't have to bring an action... an independent action.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought that there were statements in more than one of our cases to the effect that there is no removal from tribal to federal court.
And you say you don't know?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: I'm not aware of language like that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: If this case had been brought in state court under 1983, could the tribal claims that were being asserted under tribal law be pended to that action in state court?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: They could be presented to the court, Your Honor, and then I think it would be a matter of comity for the supreme court to consider whether or not to acknowledge those claims brought under tribal law.
It would be up to the state supreme court, ultimately, so it would be a question of state law.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: In other words, these claims under tribal law are left to the grace of the state.
The state can allow them if it wants to, disallow them if it wants to.
So you're saying, as far as tribal law is concerned, the tribe has no authority, and the state is not obliged to hear those claims.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Ultimately yes, that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: As you understand it, where does the tribe get its tort law?
Does it borrow Nevada law?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: As I understand it, yes.
It does... it uses Nevada law as a guide, which makes it very uncertain, but it does refer to Nevada law quite often.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And as you understand the complaint, is the liability under Nevada tort law as borrowed by the tribe, roughly coextensive with the liability under 1983, other than say for attorney's fees?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Well, first of all the state tort law supplies limits or caps on claims, which aren't available under 1983 actions, so there is some--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Does the tribal law borrow those caps as well, as you understand?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --As I understand it, they would not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, then, the liability is coextensive under the tort law theories and under 1983.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: If this were in tribal court, Your Honor, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.
And the tribal court doesn't borrow Nevada law insofar as the caps are concerned, as best you understand?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: That's correct, although I don't have an expressed statement from the court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What is... the tribal law is codified, or is it just common law developed by the tribal court, case by case?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: A little of the first and a lot of the latter, Your Honor.
There isn't law and order code, but a great deal of it, I think, is just the custom in practice.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Law and order code is civil actions, or just criminal?

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: It includes civil matters, I believe, as well as criminal.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can I still... I'm not going to give up yet on getting your opinion on this.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What the Solicitor General precisely recommends is recognizing the policy of the removal statute, namely remove... that's the policy... that you could have what the court did in El Paso which is, quote, an injunction given by a federal court against further litigation in tribal courts that in practical effect gives the same result as a removal.
Now, that's the Solicitor General's precise... which then just like removal would eliminate any possibility of conflict between state and tribal interests.
So that's what I'd like your comment on.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Okay, Your Honor.
We see a difficulty with the U.S. position, because it works very well for the federal civil rights claims.
Those are immediately removed.
The difficulty is with tribal claims, because there... the U.S. suggests there's a federal defense, but that--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In your case it would resolve because the whole case would come along, and what you'd say about other cases is sufficient unto the day.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I guess normally when you remove, the entire case goes with the--

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --So if the injunction is the same as removal, you get to the result that you want in respect to all of the claim.

turn.speaker: c_wayne_howle
turn.label: Mr. C. Wayne Howle
turn.text: Unless there were not a federal claim to begin with in order to remove it.
I'd like to reserve the rest of my time with your--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Howle.
Mr. Anaya, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
This case began when Nevada game wardens sought the approval of Fallon tribal court not once but twice, in order to come on the Fallon reservation and conduct a search against a tribal member.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, the petitioner says they didn't even need to get tribal court permission to get a search warrant.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: We disagree, and the authority of this Court will indicate the contrary.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And what do you rely on?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Williams v. Lee, and its progeny, Your Honor, which establishes clearly that the sovereignty of tribes precludes the authority of the state to the extent it interferes with the ability of the tribe to make its own laws and be governed by them.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But it's not governed by its own criminal laws insofar as a crime that occurs off the reservation is concerned.
Could this tribal court have tried this crime?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Your Honor, the tribal court... if this were a crime under tribal law, and it is not a crime under tribal law as far as I know.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The tribe can make off-reservation crimes a crime under tribal law triable in the tribal court?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It could as to members, perhaps.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, crimes by members.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: By members.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not crimes against members.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And what if they did make it triable in tribal court... would the state still be able to prosecute it as a violation of state law?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The state could, in any instance, prosecute this case.
What is at issue here is whether it can go onto the reservation to execute a warrant.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, the state's ability to prosecute is not worth a whole lot if it leaves the by your leave of somebody else to go and grab the person who allegedly did the offense.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: That may be.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's what you're saying... that the state is entirely at the mercy of the tribal court to get a search warrant, and I presume an arrest warrant as well.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is what I'm saying.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's quite an incursion on the state's criminal jurisdiction, it seems to me.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The state judge who issued the state warrant agreed with that position.
The state judge himself explicitly said on the face of the warrant that the warrant was invalid within the reservation--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He might have been wrong.
I don't know the man.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Well, he could be wrong, but we... he got it right as far as our position goes, Your Honor.

The Attorney General of Nevada himself has issued an opinion, has issued an opinion saying that the state has no authority to go on the reservation to execute searches or investigate crimes against members.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Your Honor, that's not in our brief.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I didn't think it was, and I would have sat up, and my eyes would have popped open.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, we were surprised--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Was that opinion an opinion of state law?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Yes.
Well, it was an opinion of federal law.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He was applying federal... the Attorney General of Nevada was--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The opinion was applying an interpretation of federal law, and the lower court have held the same.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --What about John Marshall, Cherokee Nation v. Georgia?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Exactly, Your Honor.
The laws of the state of Georgia have no force in the territory of the Cherokee.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that doesn't quite resolve this question, it seems to me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there some case authority, either in the Nevada courts or the federal courts, that a federal... that a state official seeking to enforce a federal, state summons or subpoena or arrest warrant can't go on the reservation unless the--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The Turtle case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --The what?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The Turtle case that we cited.
I believe it's the Ninth Circuit, which specifically precluded Arizona from going onto the Navajo reservation and trying to execute a warrant against people on the reservation.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Suppose this had been a federal officer executing a similar warrant investigating violation of federal--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Well, that would be a different matter, Your Honor.
Under the Major Crimes Act, federal officers do have jurisdiction over the reservations.

This is a state officer, and the weight of authority in the lower federal courts and in the state courts interpreting federal law is that state authorities do not have the authority to go on the reservation and execute warrants--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --How much of the authority pertains to crimes committed off reservation?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Most of it, Your Honor, or a good deal of it, at least, and the Turtle case is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Turtle?
What else?
That's a Ninth Circuit case, I gather, right?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Well, we have authority... the Attorney General's opinion that I cited to.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'd like the cite of that.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The Attorney General's Opinion Number 80-42.
Nevada Highway Patrol Jurisdiction on Indian Reservations.
Nevada... again, Opinion Number 80-42, and we can make this available--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wait... Nevada Highway Patrol.
It's just related to what?
The Highway Patrol doing what?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Does Nevada Highway Patrol acting under the authority granted by the state, have the authority to investigate accidents on a reservation?
To go onto the reservation, investigate accidents--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: An accident that occurred on the reservation?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Occurring wherever... to investigate accidents on the reservation, even to pursue someone onto the reservation.
And the Nevada Attorney General, citing federal authority, citing the opinions of other state courts, says no.
This is the common understanding.
This was the understanding of the state judge who issued the warrant.
It was the understanding of the tribal authorities that the state authorities could not go onto the reservation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not the understanding of the state here.
They had an epiphany or something.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: I think that's right... they did have an epiphany.
In their opening brief, they didn't pick this position.
They did not pick this position.
You will recall that Mr. Howle, in articulating the position, now referred to the reply brief.
He did not reply to the opening brief.
This came as a surprise to us.

If they had taken that position, you can be sure we would have included sufficient authority for the proposition that the state authorities cannot go onto the reservation to investigate crimes committed even off of the reservation by nonmembers, or allegedly by nonmembers.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Anaya, we've gotten pretty far afield, I think, from what we have to resolve in this case, possibly, and there is remaining, as I understand it, a suit by Mr. Hicks against a state official in his individual capacity.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Your Honor, that's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And some other people too?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes.
No.
They're all state officials.
Three state officers who participated.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And that remains.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In their individual capacity.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The official capacity suits have been dropped.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The state says these officials have personal immunity from that suit.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: In tribal court.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And that issue was raised by them in the tribal court, right?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It's ambiguous.
They raised it in the context of a motion to quash service of process.
They raised the threshold of jurisdictional issues and conflated what appeared to be personal immunity defenses with those.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And the tribal court declined to what?
Rule specifically on the personal individual immunity?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
The tribal court only reached the threshold--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The subject matter jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And then the state went to federal district court and said, you, federal district court, should decide these issues.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: That's correct.
The state went immediately to federal district court.
The state could have--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, immediately after three years.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --After a month, after about two weeks, I think.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: A month.
Okay.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: In that time period--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --after the court ruled.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And the district court did not deal with individual immunity allegations?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It did not.
The state could have immediately moved for a motion to dismiss.
At that time we presumed that the tribal court would convene an evidentiary hearing and would have heard the personal immunity defenses, would have heard--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: No, by now we're in the federal district court.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And the district court didn't deal with it, and then it went to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, and it didn't deal with that issue, either.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The district court, nor the circuit court, dealt with the personal immunity defenses because they applied the rule of exhaustion.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is there a 1983 action here, or not?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The complaint by Mr.--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: It isn't clear to me.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --The complaint by Mr. Hicks before the tribal court pleads violations of United States constitutional law.
Those allegations have been treated as allegations under Section 1983.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, do you represent Mr. Hicks?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, I do.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And is it a 1983 action, or is it not?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: We... it is a 1983 action.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Are you aware of any court within the territory of the United States that can interpret 42 U.S.C. 1983 without review by this Court?
I suppose France or England could apply 1983 and we couldn't review their... are you aware of any court interpretation?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: I am not.
I am not, and we're not contending necessarily the tribal courts would not be subject to review.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, how would that happen?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It would happen along the device that Justice Souter has suggested... excuse me, Justice Breyer has suggested... a device that the United States has suggested as well--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Even apart from removal?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Well, that wouldn't be a review, but that would be a device by which the action could be heard by the federal court.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You mean injunction?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, an injunction.
Another possibility--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You mean an injunction after the tribal court has ruled on the issue, then you enjoin the tribal court because it's made a mistake in interpretation of federal law?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It seems to me that that's more intrusive--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --It is.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --than what they're asking for here.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: And we are not saying that we would favor that approach.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.
So under your position, there is no way to review a ruling on a matter of federal law given by the tribal court.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: That is yet to be determined... could be determined by the lower courts.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What is your position as to whether or not a ruling on an issue of federal law in a tribal court in this suit can be reviewed ultimately in a federal court?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Your Honor, Mr. Hicks at this point would choose not to take a position because in litigating the case in the tribal court, if this Court were to affirm jurisdiction, he would have to explore his options whether or not it would be to his advantage to seek some kind of review depending upon the tribal court, however--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Suppose, at least so far as I were concerned... and I can't speak for my colleagues... that the case turned on whether or not there ultimately could be review in the federal court.
Then I would say you would have to lose, because you have indicated to me that that review is problematic, or at least reserving your position, and you're later going to say there is no review.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --I simply articulated the position to Mr. Hicks.
The position of the tribe and the tribal court in this case is that there could be review.
There could be review after exhaustion, and that would be the appropriate--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: After exhaustion?
I could imagine--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --May I just pursue?
And that review consists of an injunction for some kind of abuse of discretion by the trial court, or--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --That would be more the removal theory of the United States.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Suppose the removal theory doesn't work... is there any other way to review it?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: The review mechanism would work something along the lines of the following although, again, this is uncharted territory.
The claims would be exhausted in tribal court, and then assuming that the defendants were to lose, they could then go to the federal court and seek some kind of relief against the tribal court.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What... some kind of... what kind of relief?
I've never heard of such a procedure.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Well, it would be the same kind of... essentially the same kind of action that defendants have taken in order to challenge the jurisdiction of trial courts... essentially an injunction action.

But in the course of determining whether or not an injunction should lie, the court would then review the jurisdictional issues as well as the merits, or at least the application of the law in the Section 1983 action.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why shouldn't the federal court have decided these issues of immunity of the officers when it had the case before it?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It applied the rule of exhaustion that this Court laid down in National Farmers Union, as well as Iowa Mutual v. LaPlante.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, that case really just went to exhaustion on the jurisdictional issue.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, they did, but it could be that the exhaustion could also apply to the merits, and indeed could.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But did the district court have the power to decide that issue when it had the case in front of it?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Strictly speaking, I believe it did.
This Court has articulated the exhaustion rule as one of comity, and so out of comity, out of respect for the tribal court--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it is correct, is it not, that we've never held that there must be exhaustion of anything other than the jurisdictional issues?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, that is the case.
But the exhaustion doctrine is a flexible one, and it is intended to accommodate the interests that might--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the exhaustion doctrine assumes that there is some later substantive power to exercise jurisdiction over the case, but you question whether that power ultimately exists.
You don't have exhaustion if there's not going to be some further jurisdictional substantive review.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --The position of the tribe in this case is that there could be substantive review, and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: As I understand it, the tribe's position would allow for an injunction on either or both of two grounds.

One, of course, the jurisdictional issue could be reviewed again as the basis for the injunction, and if the tribe won the jurisdictional issue, then presumably the merits of the 1983 claim could also be litigated in the federal court, and if the federal court thought the tribal court was wrong on that, it would enjoin enforcement of the judgment.
Is that correct?
Is that the way it would work?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you'd have to wait until the end of the line, and that seems to be at odds with the notion of qualified immunity that you get out sooner rather than later.

Here your positing a case... and I think the Ninth Circuit supported it... that you must exhaust in the tribal court, even your qualified immunity defense, you must exhaust in the tribal court before you can come over to seek an injunctive relief in the federal court.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Right.

The way we contemplate it working, if such an exhaustion were to apply to a 1983 cause of action or to the tribal cause of action in this case, would be for the tribal court to immediately move forward to determine the qualified or personal immunity defenses.
And at that point, the defendant could go to federal court to seek review of that prior to an adjudication of the merits of the claim in the tribal court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Even in the federal court system, as I recall it, we allow the denial of qualified immunity to be appealed immediately, because, you know, the belief is that the important interests served by it are simply defeated if you wait until the whole litigation is finished before you tell the governmental agent, well, you don't have to worry about it.
Why should there be a different rule when we go that far to allow such an interlocutory appeal in the federal system?
It seems very strange to require the government official to go all the way through the tribal court and await an injunction afterwards.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Well, what we're suggesting, or what the model would suggest, is that there would be the opportunity to go immediately upon a determination in the tribal court of the qualified immunity defense to the federal court, so it would be in the nature of a interlocutory review.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then if you lost and you went back and you exhausted on the merits, there would be another opportunity to go into the federal court for a different injunction.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
I didn't understand.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You would allow it immediately as soon as the qualified immunity--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But would it not have been consistent with our cases for the district court in this case to have said I'm going to decide the qualified immunity issue right away.
He didn't do that... it would have been consistent with our cases for the district judge to have done that, would it not?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Perhaps, Your Honor, but the rationale of National Farmers Union of Iowa Mutual, I think, counseled in favor of what the district court did.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If you assume the rationale of exhaustion applies beyond jurisdictional issues.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And I think--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It has not been decided.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --And I think it does.
The rationale is to support the self-governance of the tribe, and to support the development of tribal courts and their autonomy.
And for the district court to have ruled on something--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but it supports them to the same extent that it would respect the sovereignty of the states.

Of course, if it were a state court involved, they would respect the jurisdiction, require exhaustion on the jurisdictional issue, but nevertheless might have gone ahead on the merits, if this were a state court rather than a tribal court.
You're in effect asking for a stronger rule of exhaustion in tribal courts than if it were a state court.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, we think that the situation here is one in which we have a tribal court struggling to maintain its jurisdiction, and the deference that the exhaustion doctrine gives to tribal courts is warranted, and the interests of the state officials... the federal interest that might exist in ensuring that their interests are protected, are sufficiently met by the exhaustion rule as long as there is some kind of review and, perhaps, an interlocutory review of the personal immunity defenses.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do tribal courts routinely hear Section 1983 federal claims?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: Not routinely, Your Honor, but there is nothing... there is no federal law that precludes them from hearing a 1983 claim.
The Fallon tribal court is a court of general jurisdiction.

The 1983 statute is a jurisdiction intended to provide broad remedies for violations of constitutional rights and, in the absence of an affirmative limitation on the jurisdiction of the court, the tribal court, under federal law, it seems to follow quite naturally that the Fallon tribal court as a court of general jurisdiction would have jurisdiction to hear a Section 1983--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It is still not clear to me the theory on which any such... any tribal court determinations on such matters can be reviewed in any federal court.
What is the theory?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --The theory is that there is a federal interest in ensuring that the state defendants' immunity defenses would be sufficiently aired--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So is it a federal question?
Use federal question jurisdiction to this--

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --Well, that's right.

This would assume that immunity defenses would be defenses under federal law, and that is the position that the United States has taken, and it's a position that the tribe accepts... that these defenses could become federal law and hence they would be the basis for review in federal court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --There are other situations where we just fire off injunctions where we think a federal interest may be involved?
Do we have authority to do that?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: This is a unique context, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yeah, it sure is.

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: It is.
And the unique context and wrinkles that exist here are because of historical situations and patterns that have existed, that have arisen and continued, and require this Court to--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, maybe they require.
I mean, there are two conclusions that you could draw from the absence of any review provision in the tribal court for a 1983 action.
One is that we could invent some never-before-heard-of, and never-elsewhere-used power of this Court or federal courts to issue an injunction.
The other one is that the tribal court has no authority to entertain 1983 actions.
That would solve the problem just as well, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: s_james_anaya
turn.label: Mr. S. James Anaya
turn.text: --That would solve the problem, just like--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But not your client's problem.
I understand that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Anaya.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. McDowell, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The tribal court has jurisdiction over Mr. Hicks' civil damages suit against the state game wardens in their personal capacities.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, how about a 1983 action?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: Well, we would say that the federal courts have concurrent jurisdiction over that sort of action, as in El Paso Natural Gas.
We think that there should be an opportunity effectively to remove the case to federal court through an injunction.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I agree, but does it exist?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: To the extent it existed in El Paso, Your Honor, it exists here as well.
Congress has expressed its preference for a federal forum at a defendant's request when he has been sued on a federal cause of action.
That occurs through the removal statute when the defendant is sued in state court.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the Wheeler Act... is that the Act... the Nuclear Power Act... had a specific provision for exclusive jurisdiction.
We don't have that here.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: Exclusive jurisdiction, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The El Paso case was not a removal case.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Yes, it was, with respect, Your Honor.
It was a removal case.
It was a case in which there was--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Excuse me... there was an underlying congressional act which gave exclusive jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Only if the defendant raised it, Your Honor, the case would be free to proceed in state court for a nuclear tort, or in tribal court, unless the defendant sought a federal forum.
That was the case in El Paso as we understand it, and that would also be the case here.
The cases under 1983 could proceed in tribal court, but if the defendant elects a federal forum, he should be entitled to that at the outset of the case so that the trial of the facts--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Really making up a statute that Congress didn't pass because that's what happens... a federal officer is sued in state court.
He can remove it.
Why can he remove it?
Because Congress has said so.
So here Congress has said nothing at all.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Well, that's correct, Your Honor.
That was also the case in El Paso, but the court didn't think that Congress' silence in that instance reflected any specific intent to leave the case in tribal court if a defendant wanted it in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But they don't have to have any intent to leave it in trial court, you need an intent to get it removed from tribal court.
The extant state of affairs is what it is.
What we're looking for is some reason to remove it.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Well, the reason to remove it is because the plaintiff has asserted a federal cause of action, and we would think that Congress would want a defendant sued in tribal court to have the same right as the defendants sued in state court to get a federal forum.

We think that Congress' failure to provide in Section 1441 for removal from tribal court was inadvertent, it doesn't reflect a policy choice on the part of Congress that such cases should remain in tribal court.
Simply the fact that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I don't mean to cut you off... I thought maybe you would address this.

El Paso was a stronger case for your position in one respect, at least, because in El Paso, I think, as I recall it, the federal statute preempted all other causes of action so that the federal right was, in effect, was exclusive, because you don't have that feature here.
So if there's an injunction in this case on the El Paso model, it in effect would leave the litigation to go forward on non-1983 claims arising, I mean, for example, tribal tort claims.
So the result would sort of be a bifurcation of the litigation and sort of a mess, and you didn't have that feature in El Paso.
Shouldn't that bear on the question of whether or not we want to follow the El Paso model here?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --We don't think that would be the necessary result, Your Honor.
As with removal from state court, any pendent state causes of action follow the federal cause of action.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay, but I mean this is getting Rube Goldberg.
Now there's another rule and pendent jurisdictional claims are now being removed by means of a novel use of injunction.
I mean, there's a character here that we're making up an awful lot as we go along on your theory.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: Well, there is a common law nature to much of this Court's jurisprudence with respect to Indian law, certainly the cases--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But what is the justification, then, for saying to the tribes that they could not proceed in their related tort actions in the tribal courts merely because we think the 1983 action should be enjoined for purposes of quasi-removal.
What is the basis for saying that they can't receive in their own courts under their own law?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Well, they certainly can choose to proceed in their own courts.
They're the masters of their complaints, and they can drop the 1983--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but what I'm getting at is your notion that all... that these tribal tort law claims would be deemed pendent to the 1983 actions and enjoined with them.
I am saying what is your basis for saying... is it simply a basis of convenience to the defendant?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Well, that's typically the treatment of state law claims when we remove to federal court.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But we've got a statute on it.
We've got a statute.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: How does it work?
That is, in your view on the tribal claims.

Your view is that the torts... if the tribe... suppose the tribe has a strict liability tort theory and there is no defense of official action, and it says that all the FBI agents, Bivens agents, Department of Interior agents, anybody you want in the federal government, is now going to be strictly liable for their torts, okay?
Now, in your view they could just go do that.
That's the government's view.
That's the federal government's view.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: There would be federal immunity defenses.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But where do they come from?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: They come from the federal government's unique interest in law enforcement on reservations.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So if they're going to have... and are we now going to have a new sort of federal government thing we're making up, which... well, then why not have it all in the federal court?
I mean, I'm a little worried about what we're getting into when we're making these things up.
That's not meant to be a criticism... I'm just quite... having a hard time foreseeing where this case is going.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why does the federal government have a unique interest in law enforcement?
My goodness... it's not only not unique, its interest in law enforcement is a good deal less than that of the states.
They do most of the law enforcement in this country.

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: Not with respect to Indian reservations, Your Honor.
The federal government is the principal law enforcement authority on the reservations.
It is delegated some of that authority--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not with respect to state crimes that occur off the reservation.
I mean, I can see the state... can I ask you?

It matters to me... it may not matter to anybody else, but can you resolve the conflict here as to whether state officers are allowed just on the basis of a state warrant to enter a reservation to pursue a criminal from state justice for a crime that occurred off the reservation?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: --Not in the circumstances of this case.
Footnote seven of our brief cites some cases on the proposition.
I think the way of looking at this is in the state/state context.

If somebody commits a criminal offense in Nevada, yes, Nevada has the right to prosecute that offense, but if the person goes to California, perhaps even lives in California, if Nevada wants to execute a search warrant against that person's California home, the Nevada warrant isn't self-executing.
There is a need to go to a California court to get approval of the search, and we would say that the same model applies in the state/tribe situation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In that situation, I'm just thinking, aren't you really on the other side?
Imagine this is only the 1983 action.
What's the difference between your position and their position?
Their position is that the 1983 action has to be brought in federal court.
Your position is that it has to be brought in federal court as long as the defendant wants to do it.
That seems to me the only practical difference.
Am I right?

turn.speaker: barbara_b_mcdowell
turn.label: Ms. Barbara B. McDowell
turn.text: As a practical matter, that may well be correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Then you have to think that the Ninth Circuit got it all wrong here, because as I take it, you're saying we let the tribal members sue in tribal court, but the defendant state officer the next day can remove it and there's nothing that the tribe or the tribal member can do about it.
